bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, February 20, 1935

div1.p: Howard writes that he will send Moran a copy of "Yellow Jack." He reports on the play's success and sympathizes with Moran's difficulties related to the Cuban revolution.

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, February 20, 1935

opener.dateline:
SIDNEY HOWARD
18 HIBBEN ROAD
PRINCETON, NEW JERSEY
February 20th,
1935.

div1.p:
Your letter certainly reminds me that I never
finished one which I started to write you when yours
reached me on the island of Crete last spring. Please
forgive me. I was glad to have yours and to put it
away to keep among my precious documents. I did start
to answer it at once and in the middle of it the type-
writer got knocked on the floor and never was the same
again and somehow I couldn't inflict my handwriting
on you. A copy of YELLOW JACK goes forward, properly
inscribed, almost at once. I doubt its being played
in the movies, but it is being done all over the country
as a play in different colleges and has had a great
success in Holland and Stockholm and is probably going
to be played presently in London, Moscow and Vienna.
So you see that our story is getting about into some
new territory.

I am sorry indeed to hear the bad news you
report about yourself and I hate to think of your thinking
of leaving your pleasant home in Havana. I remember wondering
how you had come through the revolution and asking you about
that when last I wrote you, but I had hoped that the Sun Oil
Company was weathering the depression without too much dif-
ficulty. I certainly will put my ear to the ground for a
Latin American job, but my ear doesn't cover a great deal
of ground on which the footsteps of such jobs are to be heard.
If you come to New York you are certainly required to let
me know -- I have said that before. The old address: 157
East 82nd Street, is still good, though I am living here
until June 1st. Every good wish to Mrs. Moran and to you.
div1.closer: Faithfully yours, Sidney Howard. John J. Moran, Esquire.
